reviews.author: YSA
reviews.title: Mandatory course, could be worse
reviews.comment_content:
IMPORTANT
This course has 3 sections (L1, L2, L3) and each section has a completely different topic or theme, so what you learn in one section is completely different from the others. I suggest you check the topics of each section before selecting one, as they change every term/year I think.
Mine was L1: Happiness, self-interest and morality. Basically about different philosophical theories and ideas, sometimes a bit boring, but it was a more general theme, unlike other sections which focused on particular philosophies like Confucianism
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching during the lectures was boring... Of 400 people in the lecture about 300+ were sleeping or watching movies/chatting most of the time.
The instructor for the writing workshops was very good though. Very helpful and attentive, gives good, specific feedback at every step of the essay.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was not too bad. No exams, there are 2 quizzes, a final essay, and several small online assignments.

Quizzes are 20 MCQs, extremely easy if you just go through the PPTs of each lecture. No need to attend lectures or assigned reading.

Online assignments are mostly Canvas quizzes with unlimited attempts, so always 100%
reviews.comment_workload:
Seems like a lot of workload initially, with essay, quizzes, assigned reading, assignments, but it's not so bad.
Assigned readings and attendance at lectures not important at all (at least for my section, not sure about others)
Online assignments are very quick and easy
Online discussions every 2 weeks or so, don't take a lot of time but are annoying
Essay is the main work, but as they make you right parts of it (intro, body, conclusion) in the assignments, you basically write most of the essay automatically by the end

reviews.author: Galen
reviews.comment_content:
Cultures and Values (L3): Morality and Emotions in Philosophy, Literature and Film

From the syllabus: (This course will explore the values of morality, love and beauty across diverse cultures in relationship to the individual’s emotional well-being and chance to have a fulfilled life. We will address the following issues as reflected in a range of philosophical writings, literature, film and art: universal and culturally particular aspects of ethics and human nature; different conceptions of romantic love; as well as the appreciation of beauty and art.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
You should expect the lectures to be boring and monotone. But the lecturer tries her best to make it fun and interactive.

As for the tutorials, I was fortunate enough to have Amy Chi. She is very nice, assertive at times. But she gets the job done. She gave me solid suggestions and critical feedback on the essay draft which was important for me to get an A for this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% quiz（Based on assigned readings）
10% LMES forum
10% video presentation
20% writing workshop
50% essay

I got an A for this course.
reviews.comment_workload: I put relatively minimal effort in this course. The most stressful thing or was a hassle was writing a short essay in the discussion section every week. (*The questions are assigned by the TA)

reviews.author: kwkli
reviews.comment_content: You have different content to choose but I think they all require little knowledge. Just try to pick for the one that seems more interesting or more popular professor will do. I previously took "Happiness" in this course and it included a lot of the philosophy stuff, trying to convince us about what is true happiness. It may seems quite boring though.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof was not so successful in catching students attention to his lecturing, so the classes were always half-emptied.
Tutorials really depends on tutors' style of teaching, but most of them just focus on language skills and participation in class discussions.
reviews.comment_grading: I believe that as long as you finish all the readings and then that will be fine for your quizzes. Effort shown in the grade in this course. The harder you try to work for your essay, the better grade you could get.
reviews.comment_workload: It could be high since there're many require readings, and you are not allowed to skip the tutorial sections. But there's neither mid-term nor final exam, just two quizzes throughout the semester. So it's attractive to most students.

reviews.author: caccc
reviews.comment_content: the topic of my section：the basic values of economic development，legal justice，and social diversity
reviews.comment_teaching:
lecture--take attendance by PRS
tutorial--take attendance
reviews.comment_grading:
10% quiz（twice，based on assigned readings）
10% lmes forum
10% video presentation
20% writing workshop
50% essay
reviews.comment_workload:
Electrical devices could be used and discussions were allowed during quiz, so it's pretty easy to get the right answers if you are staying with your friends to look for the answers concurrently.

For the essay, I think the most important thing is to improve your essay by what your instructor had suggested.

reviews.author: kyln
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite boring. Basically you are using english to study chinese culture. But you may still learn some philosophical thinking from the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is teaching in monotone and it makes the lecture not that appealing to listen. He did always encourage students to present their ideas in lectures so you still have to get prepared despite the boring lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: Despite the boring content, the essays/ discussion forum posts that you have to do are nothing really related to the lecture powerpoint. Although you have to relate something back to the readings/lecture notes, you can basically do research on the internet. The grade is quite good.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is average. You have to hand in an essay at the end of the semester. For each tutorial, you may have to hand in the draft of your essay to the TA. And there is only one tutorial in two weeks.

reviews.author: saka
reviews.comment_content: quite interesting. My lecture was about traditional Chinese beliefs, you can learn many interesting ideas raised by different Chinese or even foreign philosophers.
reviews.comment_teaching: interactive. He would randomly pick some students to answer questions.
reviews.comment_grading: quite good but this depends on different tutors. When you follow instructions from tutors and attend lessons punctually, this will not be a problem.
reviews.comment_workload: you will only need to write a short essay around 1000 words and take a video as your progress report. As compared to other SSC-HUMA courses, this is a really easy course.

reviews.author: HT
reviews.comment_content: If you are interested in the topics, you will find it interesting. Topics generally include morality and values. For me, I think it is a bit boring.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof is well-prepared for the lectures as he is familiar with the notes and the points that he would like to elaborate.
TA is quite nice as well. She will teach you a lot about how to construct the final essay and may give you some useful comments for improvement.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair/easy grade
reviews.comment_workload: Acceptable. There will be two quizzes, one video presentation and one final essay. There will be attendance for the lectures and tutorials as well.

reviews.author: Vivianchan95
reviews.title: huma1000
reviews.comment_content:
i think the content is quite ok, but may be a little bit boring to some students
some contents are interesting and not very boring. they may be useful in our final essay, but I  skipped most of  the Lectures as they are time consuming and i am not able to learn a lot in the class (because i studies chinese literature before, therefore, when talking about chinese traditional values, I will rather skip the class)
reviews.comment_teaching:
if u are in the tutorial class of Mr John Fung, You are quite lucky, because personally, his class is interesting and not very boring.  I think tutorial classes are similar with Lang1002/Lang1003,teaching with videos and powerpotins.  
i think it  is quite ok, but may be a little bit boring to some students . i think not many things to talk about teaching as different tutors may have different methods. but personally Mr john fung is good in giving advice and the grade given by him is quite good
reviews.comment_grading:
ok.
finished all the assignments and don't miss any quizzes and tutorial classes, you will get a good grade.
Good english is needed as the better the english the easier to get a better grade.
and most of the people who have a clear mindset, good english and attend all the tutorial classes can get a B range ( date sourced by my friends)
some people think this course is bad grading, but it depends on your english proficiency and work hard.
reviews.comment_workload:
similar with Lang1002/1003.
you need to do assignments, videos, transcripts etc, and i think you have to read some readings before doing the assignments and writing the essay which is similar with our language courses.  workload is not really heavy comparing with other courses with al to of reading and exam.  This course doesn't have any exam but only one final essay, so it is a kind of relieve when you have a lot of mid-term exams or final exams. you have sufficient time to complete the assignments and essay. therefore, the workload is actually ok.   it is in acceptable range  instead of really heavy workload

reviews.author: Stetanjung
reviews.comment_content:
Basically, all of the students in HKUST have to take this course, as this is the only Humanities (Ssc) that makes sense and is reasonable, in a way.

The content is usually more about life, happiness, why is it meaningful to have love, or daily-related problems.

It may be interesting for those who like to read, or who like to learn more about the value of life.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Pretty good, the professor knows the topic really well.
He already published a book related to the topic about happiness, so he does not have any problems related to the teaching knowledge.
reviews.comment_grading:
Easy A! If you follow the rule, and you manage to do all of the assignments properly, then it is easy enough to get an A, since I think both the TA and the professor are very lenient about scoring our projects.

50% of the grading comes from the essay, 15% from 3 quizzes (easy 10 multiple choice questions which will be answered using our own clickers), 10-20% from weekly short essay that will be uploaded it in the lmes (or canvas, right now), 10-20% from the self presentation about what you have done in your essay.
reviews.comment_workload:
A little bit demanding, I guess.

We need to write a short essay in the discussion section every week. The questions are proposed by the TA, and we should do some discussions with our friends who are in the same tutorial session.

Almost at the end of the semester, we are required to do little presentation about what we have done for our essay, and what we could do to improve it. It is flexible, you can do it with ppt, record you in the video, etc.

There will be 3 quizzes related to the assigned reading that you have read weekly.

The essay takes the biggest portion, and it is basically the core of this course.

reviews.author: Terry66
reviews.comment_content: Although i'm not mad into linguistics, I gave much attention to it. Its pretty interesting to learn about language systems around the world.
reviews.comment_teaching: Tutor is nice. He have clear speaking and active in tutorial. He gave solid suggestions and critical feedback on the essay draft. The workshop wasn't too much of a help in developing ideas, but gave you a clear outline of what's expected from the final essay. Professor is happy to discuss our individual essays with us out of class, which is very helpful.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was fine to me, have to say its pretty generous given how much effort i paid into it. You can't really control how your peers grade you so it would be nice to try your best.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite a lot. You should show up in lectures/workshop, do the online discussions, hand in homework in time and you're pretty much set. There is exam and mid term test as other subject in ust. The 2 quizzes will test the compulsory readings and viewings.  You should also remember, if not dictate, the main arguments for the academic essays. You have to remember the plots of the film.You will be reading more to prepare for your final essay anyway. Borrowing reference book from library is a good idea.
Online discussion is required. The topic changes every week, relating to the corresponding lecture.  Your comment will be check by the instructors for the time you submit . . Pay attention to the requirements and rules they set.
Overall, I think there is quite a lot to do. Reading every week is really not necessary but if you wait till the last minute, it would not be fun, at all.

reviews.author: CC
reviews.title: Choose the right topic for yourself
reviews.comment_content:
My topic: Morality, Love and Beauty
It's really important that you choose the topic (lecture session) that interests you the most. Many L1/L2 students told me they found the philosophy boring or hard but I really enjoyed most of my lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Most of the lectures are interesting. Professor explains things clearly. I believe she took a lot of time to prepare the lectures. She goes through the assigned readings during the lectures so it is quite frustrating when you have already read them on your own. I think the morality part is the best because the moral dilemmas are interesting. Professor is happy to discuss our individual essays with us out of class, which is very helpful.
Personally, I think the first few workshops are not really useful. The later ones are more important for they give you clear examples of essay: what they are looking for.
reviews.comment_grading:
PRS questions in class (happens randomly)

Quiz *2

3 minutes presentation video
[Bonus: 8 minutes in-class presentation (1 student from each tutorial group)]

1000-word essay

I made quite a lot of mistakes in the 2nd quiz which may had been covered by my in-class presentation bonus. Then I made many improvements to my first draft, according to the tutor's advice and the exemplar essays and finally got an A. The professor told me it was mainly the tutor's decision when it comes to grading but the tutor said that's the professor's job. Who knows? I would suggest you to play by their rules. Make any changes that they ask you to and you shall be fine.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are about 1~2 assigned readings and movies(compulsory and supplementary) for each week. You can look for summary for the longer stories online as a shortcut. The compulsory readings and viewings will all be tested separately in the 2 quizzes. For the academic essays, you have to remember the main arguments. For the films, you have to remember the plots. I think going through the readings 3 times and the films 1 time would be sufficient to pass the quizzes. You will be reading more to prepare for your final essay anyway.
Online discussion is required. The topic changes every week, relating to the corresponding lecture.  The instructors can see the time you submit your comment. If you do it all on the last date, they might deduct some scores. Pay attention to the requirements they set.
Overall, I think there is quite a lot to do. Reading every week is really not necessary but if you wait till the last minute, it would not be fun, at all.

reviews.author: boosit
reviews.title: Linguistics
reviews.comment_content: Sadly im not a fan of linguistics so it's only natural not to give much attention to it. Nonetheless ts still pretty interesting to learn about language systems around the world.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nice tutor, gave solid suggestions and critical feedback on the essay draft. The workshop wasnt too much of a help in developing ideas, but gave you a clear outline of whats expected from the final essay.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was fine to me, have to say its pretty generous given how much effort i paid into it. You can't really control how your peers grade you so it would be nice to try your best.
reviews.comment_workload: Barely none. Just show up in lectures/workshop, do the online discussions, hand in homework in time and you're pretty much set.

reviews.author: B
reviews.comment_content: Various topics on human nature and the views of well-known philosophers. Can be interesting if you like philosophy but it wasn't very engaging for me personally. You pick 1 topic out of the 3 to write an essay for.
reviews.comment_teaching: Extremely boring as the class is very long and the lecturer tends to drone on endlessly. The 10 minute break in between doesn't really help.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grading, a high % of A's in the grade breakdown according to the TA. Attendence is preferred to get a 3% bonus but not necessary to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload with just one short essay to write and a video presentation to upload with peer feedback as well as 2 quizzes which are pretty easy.

reviews.author: joyceyeung721
reviews.comment_content:
Love, life after death, human nature，會講儒家思想等等，以前有接觸過的話，好易理解

個個sem唔同內容，睇清楚岩自己先好reg
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof講書都幾悶，但Lecture基本上可以唔上，自己睇reading都冇問題


但workshop好重要，一定要上，但好輕鬆又一堂
reviews.comment_grading: 意外地好grade，essay寫得好基本上冇問題
reviews.comment_workload:
In class quiz 10%
LMES forum 10%
Essay 50%
Writing Workshop 20%
Video Presentation 10%
Bonus Points (Lecture Attendance + Best Presenters) 3+3%

望落好多野，但最重要都係份essay，上足workshop跟足佢做就冇大問題
Video同Forum不是太重要

reviews.author: Josh
reviews.comment_content: Kind of boring. The professor tried to integrate quite some Chinese culture in the beginning part of the course, and it might be a bit difficult to understand for foreign students, so be prepared. Also, expect A LOT OF words in one powerpoint slides.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Atmosphere in the lectures are ok. Sometimes it could get quite noisy but the professor calms the crowd down pretty well.

Tutors in the writing workshops are patient and they teach pretty effectively.
reviews.comment_grading: Virtually I'd say 80% of your final grade are affected by your performance in your final essay. Just pay attention in the writing workshops, where they teach you the format and logic development of your essay then you are good to go.
reviews.comment_workload:
Plenty of out of class reading material for you to read. Although personally I did not read most of them, but it is advised to do so as the content WILL appear in the in-class-quiz and they are pretty useful in your final essay.

You would need to record a video to basically report the progress of the development of your essay. It took me around 2 days to finish it.

Final essay requires around 1500 words. A piece of cake for the ones with good writing skills.

Most of your workload will come from the discussion forum. Each week they will release a new topic, and you would have to write around a few hundred words in each of them.

reviews.author: uwnawot
reviews.comment_content: Morality and happiness, quite a lot of common sense, need to read the materials before lesson if you want to understand the lesson. If not, then you can just come to class to unprepared, but need to read through a lot to prepare for the quizzes later.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor basically repeats what is on the ppt. Depending on lessons, he might ask students some discussion questions. not a must to answer.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 quizzes, MCs, easy

mainly based on the tutorial. the TA will be the one grading your essay. essay is graded based on process. if u plan to write the essay last minute and not let the TA read before hand, chances are you are going to get bad grade.

attendance will be taken in a few lectures and in all tutorials
reviews.comment_workload:
tutorial once 2 weeks. before every tutorial, an amount of workload will be assigned. need to complete if you wanna have good grade.

all essay content can be found on the reading material. if u want to go the extra mile to get good grade, then you might need to read more online materials to stand out.

reviews.author: MATH = HELL
reviews.comment_content: Moral Psychology, Justice and the “Good Life”, providing tons of history and related self-materials for you to read with the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kind of boring because of the contents taught, impossible to be fun.
The writing workshop is even worse, repeating certain contents of Lang1002 and Lang1003, instructor feedback somewhat useless to me. Instructor feedback is not useful and minimal.
reviews.comment_grading:
As long as you have your final essay performing well, you get a good grade. It does not require good language but good explanations.
p.s. Solely focused on the essay but not the lectures and workshops, gets an A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite a lot to do if you are planning to study the course thoroughly.
Overloaded self-read materials will be abysmal to read through. The writing workshops provide you with a lot of useless work that doesn't quite help you with the essay wriitng

reviews.author: dllmpopo
reviews.title: Prof Nam was hella good
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly focusing on the Chinese and  Western philosophers which I found out they were quite interesting, and aspired you to think critically.

Nam is a good professor with a sense of humour, he offered lessons in bilingual channels (mainly Canto and English), for people to have a better understanding on the theories he explained during lessons, so no worries for people who are not good in English, you can always review lectures in your own suitable channel.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Nam and Anisa are both great who are willing to clear your doubts and answering your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. There are many little quizzes to test your understandings, but they all have unlimited attempts, and they will show you the right answers right afterwards, so you just have to spend a little time on it and get it all done. (10%)

2. 2 lecture quizzes, all in open-book format, so you can team up with your friends or just directly go to discuss answers with Prof Nam, he will answers your doubts. (20%)
    
Quiz 1: 15/20
Quiz 2: 20/20

3. Attendance is not required for lectures, but is required for writing workshops, forgot to wake up one time and lost 2% of my marks. A total of 10% will be counted toward your final grade. And the tutors will help you check your essay progress during tutorials and discuss it with your peers. I also forgot to submit one of them big it was no big deal to be honest. (10%)

4. Online discussion forums (10%)

5. The final essay grade won't be shown if you haven't asked your tutor, but after following the guidelines in all your homework, it should be quite easy to get it done, got 72/96 at last. (50%)

Final grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload: The grading is pretty good, as a student who always skipped morning lectures, I still got a pretty decent grade. So this lesson is quite chill if you wanted to get a good grade and learn something from it at the same time.

reviews.author: civil佬
reviews.title: 睇tutor
reviews.comment_content:
下面3條作1條
Essay Prompts for HUMA 1000
All of these essays are meant to stimulate thought and generate a viewpoint – you, as the writer, should be conveying a clear thesis with supporting evidence. It is worth remembering that no answer within the constraints of the essay for this class (1000 words) is going to be exhaustive in responding to the prompt. Rather, you should only attempt to address one aspect of the question that you chose to focus on, using concrete examples and texts given in class as supporting evidence.

1) Humans are fundamentally social animals. The groups they belong to shape people’s views about the world: family, local community, region, nation. There are also other types of identities that one may feel very strongly about, such as class, religion, ethnicity, etc. Most people have more than one kind of identity, and each identity may be related to a different set of interests. What are some of the potential factors that can influence a person’s adoption of an identity? When multiple identities overlap, what determines which of these take precedence over others? Feel free to use relevant personal experiences, contemporary events, and news items to make your case in addition to the course’s readings.

2) “War is the mere continuation of politics by other means” is a famous line from Carl von Clausewitz’s On War. In this sense war is the use of violence in disagreements that cannot be resolved peacefully. Yet, when is it permissible to use violence in a breakdown of negotiation? How do societies justify these "exceptional" cases?

3) We live in the era of nation-states, where individual states are assumed to represent the interests of a single nation. However national groups other than the national majority live within each nation-state in the contemporary world. Should the interests of these minorities be protected or should they submit to the will of the majority? How should disagreements between the majority group and a minority group be resolved?

reviews.title: It was a course where you learn a lot of things
reviews.comment_content: There was a lot to read and learn on your own and if you wish to completely grasp the knowledge of HUMA 1000, there is a lot that you must understand. Other than that, it was quite interesting to know more about different moral values of multifarious ideological concepts; you will learn to conceptualize certain philosophies and ideologies and use it to support your argument based on things that you've learned.
reviews.comment_teaching: Honestly, the teaching methods were not as ideal, and the sad thing is that it would be rather hard for this course to improve on its teaching techniques. First of all, the lecture was rather repetitive as we as students were told to read up on the reference materials, then it turns out the professor was going to teach the same thing on the day of the lecture itself. The professor seems like an enthusiastic person as he is always fine with answering the students' questions. As for the tutors in HUMA 1000 tutorials, they seem inconsistent to a certain extent as the content of HUMA 1000 is rather broad and they themselves are not familiar with the final essay requirements.
reviews.comment_grading:
In terms of grading, the grading structure seems rather vague, but based on experience(got an A- lol), I would say if you want a good score, you need to work on these areas:
1. Language abilities: the emphasis on grading is very heavy in the final essay; if your English is bad, your grades will be bad.
2. Knowledge of philosophy: if you do not know anything about philosophy and if you do not seem to understand anything when you go for your lectures, you need to spend some time reading the reference materials they provide.
3. Be an active participant on the discussion forums: just keep arguing how you're right and how others are wrong in the comments section.
reviews.comment_workload: For most, the workload is only intense the night before the essay submission; I'd advise you to consistently allocate time for the final essay every now and then. If you're not sure on whether you are going towards the right direction, always try to ask your tutor, because although he might not be clear on the direction of grading, at least he knows more than you, which is more than enough. So just keep learning more along the way, attend the tutorials and the essay will be easy for you to write.

reviews.author: CourseReviewer
reviews.title: Useless course but good grading
reviews.comment_content:
Content is really, really bad. No practical knowledge usable in real life.

Lecture notes are only full of pictures and their sources. Even if I wanted to listen in the lectures, there's not much information that is useful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Initially thought that Lawrence was a good professor since he had a very good command of English, didn't need to refer to anything during lectures. Seemed to be a very knowledgeable guy who graduated from Harvard.

As the lesson went on, this proved to be wrong. His lessons were really boring. (as expected of a HUMA 1000 course though so there's no blaming him)

My TA was Dr. Danyal and he was amazing. Relatively funny guy with a decent sense of humor. Although his writing workshops are a bit vague, he does a really, really good job at scrutinizing your essay and making sure that you do your best. He's the only reason why the teaching is a C and not an E.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is divided as follows:
20% Quiz
10% Online Discussion
10% Writing Workshop Online Activities
10% Writing Workshop Classroom Activities
50% Final Essay
Bonus 3/4% for IPRS attendance

Quiz: Very easy quiz. Just make sure you watch all the lecture videos or attend the lectures before! Although, some questions are really vague so you gotta use some common sense. Remember to read reading material too!
I think the mean was around 12.7/20, SD around 3.

Online Discussion: Do NOT copy paste other people's work from other sessions because they actually monitor this. You might end up with an F. Make sure you post more than once (I think this helped me) and respond on time to your peers.

Online Activities: Make sure you complete all the online quizzes that have unlimited tries. Don't even need to watch the videos that come along with it.

Classroom Activities: Basically be on time and come to class for attendance taking. Every tutorial class has a 2% weighting.

Final Essay: To be honest, I feel that I have an advantage over this part since English is native to me. So if you have a good command of English, this part shouldn't be a problem for you. Although, HUMA1000 has a really specific essay format along with specific paragraph styles that need to be adhered to. You just have to learn how to make and find convincing arguments.

Overall, I got an A+. Marks were not disclosed.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is okay at the beginning, worsens towards the end since I made lots of corrections to my essay. I think that this is what helped me get a good grade though, since Danyal scrutinized many parts of my essay.

Other than that, it's probably just 1-2 hours every 2 weeks to complete the online discussion and online activities. Light workload.

reviews.author: 別問我是誰
reviews.title: 絕大部分人都要讀既 HUMA (LANG?) course
reviews.comment_content:
HUMA 1000 既 lecture 唔同 section 係唔同 topic，我當年揀既 section 係 Happiness, Self-interest, and Morality。

assessment 就有 lecture PRS, online forum (每一段時間會post一條問題，每個人都可以上去reply發表自己論點/reply其他人), writing workshop participation 同埋最後佔一半分既 1000字essay (據說唔係由教你果個 instructor 改，而係 lang staff)。
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture 悶到極點。

Writing workshop 就由 Levi 教，上堂氣氛都唔錯，有講有笑，但要有心理準備佢成日會揀人答題目。至於每到要交 draft 既時候佢都用心解答問題（印象中佢有特別開多幾個sessions比人揀去做類似Q&A），想知篇文個大方向有冇問題都可以問佢。
reviews.comment_grading:
呢科極不透明，基本上你係完全唔會知你唔同assessment拎咩分/做得好定差，最後就只會比個 grade 你。

個人認為呢個 course 係 HUMA 內容既 LANG course，如果本身英文寫作麻麻就要小心d篇essay，但當然內容都好重要，如果唔係好易 C range / D。
reviews.comment_workload:
個course 每2星期要上一次 writing workshop, 寫 draft, 寫n篇 online forum 既論點, 同埋最後 submit final essay。我個人認為都幾 chur (一黎要作長文，二黎內容悶且反感)。

如果想拎好grade d 建議認真睇d assigned readings，篇essay 既 marking scheme 包埋你用左幾多 reading 既資料落去。

reviews.author: Ryankay
reviews.title: Good course!
reviews.comment_content:
Can refer to previous reviews for more details on the chapters included.

I would say not too difficult to grasp the concepts and you don't really need to spend too much time understanding everything in detail, just make sure to work on the questions in the textbook so that you can work on the questions quickly in the final.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Blended learning was adopted, so you watch the videos each week yourself and ask her if you have any questions through email. The videos are ridiculously long and she talks a lot of irrelevant stuff, so after a while I just gave up on watching the videos and read the slides by myself, I found this to be more effective.

Honestly, it's surprising that an accounting course is adopting the blended learning policy, but it is what it is. Just self-study and do the questions in the textbook before the final as it's very similar to the actual questions in the final.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation: 10%
No idea how its calculated, she just said people who ask her questions through email or in class will get participation points. I never asked any questions. Since it was Zoom this semester, I think attendance was counted through Zoom. Just log into Zoom and do whatever you want, that's what I did.
Homework: 50%
Best 10 out of 12 counted, everyone should get full marks since answers can easily be found online
Final Exam: 40%
Pretty straightforward exam, she said questions will be similar to those in the textbook and she was right. Nothing too challenging and practicing with the questions in the textbook should help secure a decent grade.

Although I got A eventually, I would say the grading is pretty trash because it solely depends on your final and there is no transparency with the grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
One homework every week which is quite easy and can be completed quickly.
No midterm, only final exam, so workload is not a lot

Also, the quiz is also quite important, because not many students seem to do well on the quiz, and if you do well on this, you can definitely have an edge over others.
Grading Scheme:
Quiz 20%
Online Discussion 10%
Writing Workshop Online Activities 10%
Writing Workshop Classroom Activities 10%
Final Essay 50%
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not much, although if you are trying to read all the reading materials, it would take quite a few time. I do not think reading through every single reading material is necessary. Other than that, the workload is very light.

reviews.author: Tiffanytyc
reviews.comment_content: This course investigates the ideas and values of self, family, and society to better understand the mutual impact of society and culture on individuals, and of individuals on society and culture in the modern world. We will examine the above topics reflected in a variety of modern Western and Chinese philosophical, literary, cultural and filmic texts, from which to explore how the self and its relationship to family and society are conceptualized and defined in both Western and Chinese cultures. While examining how the concepts of self, family values, and social responsibilities are framed differently across the course of history in the West and China, this course also devotes attention to the interaction and appropriation of these concepts from the Western context into the Chinese context from comparative perspectives. Throughout, this introductory Humanities course aims to stimulate students to critically contemplate on their own conditions as modern individuals in the contemporary globalizing world.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching material is simple and easy to understanding with powerpoint & tutorial notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading system. Easy to obtain a better grade if you have higher English proficiency.

In-class quizzes (Multiple choice questions) 20%
Canvas online discussion 10%
Writing workshops – online content (Canvas) 10%
Writing workshop – classroom sessions 10%
Term essay (including revision efforts) 50%

Remember to finish the online discussion on time. Should also show participation by responding to at least one or two of your classmates.

reviews.author: qjk
reviews.title: Very Patriotic Professor
reviews.comment_content:
Professor PAN is a very patriotic lady who will teach you about
1. the language hegemony of English imposed upon the world by the western imperialist and capitalistic pigdogs
2. the advantages of a unified language (Mandarin) for China and benefits brought by the glorious CCP's genocide of other Chinese languages such as Cantonese
3. the successful example of Singapore's minority language genocide and how they built a strong national identity through genociding minority Chinese languages such as Cantonese and Hokkien and forcing everyone to speak Mandarin.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures are very interesting. Professor PAN will read the powerpoints back to you during the lesson, so you can skip them and read the powerpoints yourself.

The tutorial sessions (optional) are completely useless. The TA will NOT bother to read your draft essay before giving useless feedback. When you show up to the tutorial session, you will spend more time explaining your essay to the TA than he will spend giving you feedback. The TA will tell give "feedback" like "yeah you need to work on that".

Just from the look on the TA's face I could tell he didn't want to be there.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Writing Workshop Online Activities
10% Online Discussion
10% Writing Workshop Classroom Activities
50% Final Essay
20% In-class Quiz

Warning: ZERO transparency. No grades are released for the Online Discussion and Final Essay despite them counting for 60% of the course grade. Also statistics like mean and SD are not released. All you get is a grade.

Writing Workshop Online/Classroom Activities: unlimited tries, so you should get full marks. If you miss the deadline you will get zero marks Ms PUN is a very strict lady.

Online Discussion: they will give you a topic about the course material and you discuss it with your classmates in a sort of online forum. There are some very patriotic students from the Mainland who will tell you things like "Mandarin is superior to Cantonese". (Literally had this argument with an NDS)

Final Essay: 1000 word essay, choose 1 topic out of 3

In-class Quiz: 20 question MC test at the end of the semester.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload. Weekly online assignments will take about 30 minutes per week. The essay will take about a week if you work on it everyday, but again don't expect any help from the TA.
